steps.title: Check the units of your syringe.
steps.content: Check the units of your syringe. There are many different sizes of syringes. Most will be clearly marked in milliliters (mL). You'll see hash marks on the tube of the syringe. Each 1 marks a certain number of milliliters or fractions of milliliters. [1] X Research source Some syringes, such as those used to measure insulin , are marked in numbers of "units" rather than milliliters. Some older or non-standard syringes may also use different units.

steps.title: Count the lines on a syringe marked in even-numbered increments.
steps.content: Count the lines on a syringe marked in even-numbered increments. Most syringes include incremental hash marks between larger, numbered ones. For instance, you might have a syringe that is marked large lines at 2 mL, 4 mL, and 6 mL. Halfway between each of these large lines, you might see a slightly smaller line. In between each numbered line and the slightly smaller line, you would then see 4 even smaller lines. [2] X Research source Each of the smallest lines would count for 0.2 mL. For instance, the first line above the 2 mL line would equal 2.2 mL, the second line above it would equal 2.4 mL. The mid-sized line halfway between each number would equal the odd number in between. For example, the halfway mark between 2 mL and 4 mL equals 3 mL, and the mark halfway between 4 mL and 6 mL equals 5 mL.

steps.title: Read a syringe marked in consecutive increments.
steps.content: Read a syringe marked in consecutive increments. For instance, your syringe may be marked with a number at every successive mL. In between you'll see a mid-sized line that marks half mL units, like 0.5 mL, 1.5 mL, 2.5 mL, and so on. The 4 smaller lines between every half mL and mL line each mark 0.1 mL. [3] X Research source So, if you need to measure 2.3 mL, draw the liquid to the third line above the 2 line. If you need to measure 2.7 mL, that will be the second line above the 2.5 mL mark. Your syringe may be marked in other increments, such as multiples of 5 mL or in fractions of 1 mL. If so, the principle stays the sameâ€”just look for the major numbers marked on the syringe, and count the smaller marks in between.

steps.title: Measure in between the hash marks, if necessary.
steps.content: Measure in between the hash marks, if necessary. Sometimes you will be asked to measure an amount that is not exactly marked by the hash lines on your syringe. To do this, you'll have to count between the lines. [4] X Research source For instance, say you have been asked to measure 3.3 mL of a medication, but your syringe Is marked in hash marks of 0.2 mL increments. Pull the medication up the syringe and then push the plunger down until the medication is between the 3.2 mL and 3.4 mL lines.

steps.title: Hold the syringe by its flange.
steps.content: Hold the syringe by its flange. Grasp the syringe by the winged parts located on the end of the syringe opposite from the tip. This is known as the flange. Holding the syringe this way makes it so your fingers won't be in the way while you try to read the syringe. [5] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Holding the syringe this way is also important for super-precise, scientific measurements, to ensure that your body heat from your fingers doesn't distort the material you're measuring in the syringe. For everyday measurements (like home medications), you don't need to worry about body heat distortion.

steps.title: Over-fill the syringe.
steps.content: Over-fill the syringe. Always use a syringe that is larger than the amount you need to measure. Insert the needle into the liquid you want to measure, then slowly pull back on the plunger until the syringe is filled past the mark for the amount you need to measure. [6] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source For instance, if you are measuring out 3 mL of a children's medication, use a 5 mL or larger syringe. Pull the plunger back until the liquid fills the syringe past the 3 mL mark.

steps.title: Release the plunger until it is at the mark you need to measure by.
steps.content: Release the plunger until it is at the mark you need to measure by. Still holding the syringe in your hand, slowly push down on the end of the plunger with your thumb until its edge is even with the point you need to measure by. [7] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source For instance, if you are measuring 3 mL of a medication, push the plunger down until it is even with the 3 mL mark.

steps.title: Read from the top ring of the plunger.
steps.content: Read from the top ring of the plunger. No matter what syringe you use, always look at the part of the plunger closest to the tip when reading it. This will be the part touching the liquid that you are measuring. The part of the plunger closest to the top of the syringe is irrelevant and not meant to be used for measuring. [8] X Trustworthy Source HealthyChildren.org Health information from the American Academy of Pediatrics. Go to source
